div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.p: For Rent, two large Rooms, on Main street. Apply to
div3.closer:
John W. Davies,
Taylor's Music Store. se 12--3t*

div3.p:
For Rent, a furnished House in a pleasant part of the city.
For terms, address "E. S.," with references, Dispatch office.

div3.head: For Rent, three very Neatly-furnished Rooms
div3.p:
--two chambers and a parlor — with gas, water, and use of kitchen, if desired, in a private family, and a quiet, desirable neighborhood, within ten minutes walk of the Capitol, upon very moderate terms.
Also, two very pleasant Unfurnished Rooms, with gas in each.
For terms, apply to
div3.closer:
Notary public,
At Quartermaster-General's office. se 12--3t*

div3.p:
For Rent, a very desirable Dwelling-House, with eight rooms, a spacious yard, out-houses, &c., on Nineteenth street, one door from Grace.
Possession given on 1st October.
Apply to Mrs. Branch, Franklin street, between Eighteenth and Nineteenth.

div3.head: Rooms For Rent.
div3.p:
--A small private family, having more Rooms than they want, desire to rent a portion of their house, which is well furnished, to four grown persons, who will have every convenience.
The residence is on Grace street, and one of the most desirable in the city.--Address, with name and reference, through the city post-office, to "R. E. W."
For Rent, a Nicely-furnished Room, suitable for a gentleman and wife, or two single gentlemen, with gas and attendants, on Eighteenth street, one door from Broad.

For Rent, a new and well-finished Brick House, with six large and convenient rooms, two of which are in the basement, situated on Seventeenth street, between Grace and Broad streets, in a very pleasant and convenient locality.
It has a large back yard.
Apply next door to

div3.head: Rooms For Rent.
div3.p:
--Two very pretty Rooms, in a nice neighborhood, and part of one that is occupied by a gentleman.
The rent is cheap for a suitable tenant.
Apply to
div3.closer:
W. A. Mountcastle,
Broad street, between Fifth and Sixth. se 10--2t*

div3.head: For Rent.
div3.p:
--Will be rented at auction, for twelve months, on Monday, September 12th, at 12 o'clock M., on the premises, (Brook Avenue, between Clay and Leigh streets,) near Smith's grocery, a Brick residence, at present occupied by Colonel Vowles, containing five Rooms, Kitchen, Coal house, small Garden, &c. Possession given on the 16th instant.
It can be rented privately.

For Rent, one large Brick Tenement on Broad street, between Fourth and Fifth streets, suitable for a store and dwelling, now occupied by Mr. A. Spotts as a jewelry establishment.
It contains a large store, besides eight rooms, with modern improvements, a large yard, with a two-tenement kitchen.
Possession given by the 1st October.
For terms, apply to
div3.closer:
Mrs. Elizabeth Ruff,
Corner Broad and Jefferson streets. se 9--6t*

div3.p:
For Rent, or For Sale, a complete set of Chamber Furniture.
Let me hear through the post-office as soon as possible.
Address "L. S. D.," Box 25, Richmond, Virginia.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, Va., August 26, 1864.
div3.p: Regulations For Carrying into effect the Act of Congress Approved June 13, 1864, Authorizing Owners of Registered eight Per Cent. Bonds, issued under the Provisions of the Act Approved, may 16, 1861, to Exchange the same For Coupon Bonds.--Parties owning registered eight per cent. bonds under the act of May 16, 1861, desiring to exchange them for coupon bonds, will assign them, in the manner pointed out in the printed endorsement on the back of the certificate, to the "Confederate States of America, in exchange for coupon bonds, " and cause them to be presented to the Register of the Treasury Department, who will thereupon, in compliance with the provisions of the act of June 13, 1861, issue coupon bonds for the amount specified in the registered bonds so assigned.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America.
div3.p:
Loans on the Security of the five hundred Million Six Per Cent. Non-Taxable Bonds, under the Seventh Section of the Currency law.--Deposits on call will be received by the Treasurer in this city, Assistant Treasurers at Charleston and Mobile, and the Depositaries at Wilmington, Raleigh, Columbia, Augusta, Savannah and Montgomery, and certificates will be issued for the same, bearing interest at the rate of four per cent. per annum, and secured by the hypothecation of an amount of the above bonds equal to the sum of these loans.
The bonds to be set apart by the Treasurer, and the proceeds, when sold, applied exclusively to the payment of the said certificates.

The security and convenience afforded to banks and other corporations, and to the public generally, by this mode of temporary investment, and the effect of the measure, if generally adopted, in keeping the currency within moderate bounds, it is hoped will commend it to the favorable consideration of the community and secure their prompt co-operation in carrying it into effect.
div3.closer:
G. A. Trenholm,
Secretary of the Treasury.
Richmond, July 22, 1864. au 22--ts

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, August 8, 1864.
div3.p:
Certificates of Indebtedness Bearing Six Per Cent. Per Annum interest and free from Taxation. --By the fourteenth section of the act to reduce the currency, approved February 17, 1864, the Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to issue the above certificates, payable two years after the ratification of a treaty of peace with the United States.
They cannot be sold, but are only to be issued to such creditors of the Government as are willing to receive the same in payment of their demands.
They must also be given at par, though free from taxation.

The attention of purchasing agents and disbursing officers of the Government is called to this class of public securities as offering peculiar advantages to those from whom the supplies of the Government are bought and to facilitate the use of them, checks drawn by disbursing officers upon the depositaries holding these funds, and marked across the face "payable in certificates of indebtedness," will be paid in conformity therewith.
Depositaries are hereby authorized and required to comply with this regulation, and to make application to the Register for supplies of certificates as required.
div3.closer:
[Signed] G. A. Trenholm,
Secretary of Treasury. au 22--ts

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, July 28, 1864.
div3.p:
Taxed Treasury Notes.--In order to promote, as far as practicable, the early liquidation by the Treasury of the Outstanding Taxed Notes, the Treasurer, Assistant Treasurer, and Pay Depositaries in the different States, are hereby authorized to receive the said notes, except the $100 notes, at 66 per centum, on deposit, issuing for same certificates of loan, upon hypothecation of non-taxable bonds.
The said certificates to be payable on demand after the expiration of ninety days.
And all agents for the sale of the above bonds are hereby authorized to receive the taxed notes, with the exception above named, in payment of bonds, when sold, at the rate of 66 per centum.

div3.head:
Office Virginia Cotton and Wool Card
Manufacturing Company,
Richmond, September 2, 1864.
div3.p:
Dividend Notice.--A dividend of ten Per Cent. has been declared on the capital stock of the Virginia Cotton and Wool Card Manufacturing Company, payable at the office of the Company on and after the 15th of September.
By order of the Board of Directors.

div3.head: New Bakery.
div3.p: --The subscriber, having commenced the Baking Business, would respectfully ask the patronage of all his acquaintances, and the public generally, at the Bakery on Franklin street, between Seventeenth and Eighteenth streets, where will be found the usual assortment in the line of business.

Persons Entitled to Provision Tickets for September, residing between Sixth and Ninth streets, north of Broad street, will apply for them on Monday Next at the office of Mr. William P. Munford, next to the Enquirer office.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--An adjourned meeting of the Iron Masters of the State of Virginia will be held in Richmond at the office of the Old Dominion Nail Company on Wednesday, the 28th September instant.
A full attendance is earnestly requested.

div3.head:
Richmond theatre,
corner Seventh and Broad streets.
div3.p: Acting and Stage Manager...R. D. Ogden.
Monday Evening, September 12, 1864.

First night
of the engagement of the talented Tragedienne,
Miss Katie Estelle;
upon which occasion she will appear as
Blanche,
in Mrs. Anna Cora Mowatt Ritchie's beautiful and
elegant five-act Play of
Armand.

Mr. R. D. Ogden as...Armand,
with all the Company in the Cast.
Ballad...Miss. Blanche Middleton.

Conclude with
the Militia of '76.
Cobus...J. Wells.

To-morrow (Tuesday).
Complimentary Benefit
of
R. D. Ogden;
upon which occasion Miss. Ida Vernon, Sallie Partington and Mr. E. R. Dalton will appear in the burlesque of
Pocahontas.

div3.head: Metropolitan Hall.
div3.p:
Monday night,
and every Evening this Week,
Berch's Nightingales
will appear with
New Songs, Glees, Jokes, Dances and Burlesques.

Hall crowded nightly with the beauty and fashion of the capital to witness.
Birch's Minstrels.

Gentlemen are respectfully informed that they can visit the Hall with their wives, sweethearts, mothers and sisters, without fear of hearing any vulgar or obscene language, as the proprietors guarantee that all their efforts to amuse and entertain them shall consist of innocent Jokes, Songs, Burlesques, &c.
The Nightingales are composed of the best talent that can be procured.

list.item: George Reems, the witty Brudder Bones.
George Reems, the celebrated Negro Delineator.
George Reems, every night, every night.
F. H. Rix, the renowned Tamborinist.
F. H. Rix, the great Comedian.
F. H. Rix, nightly, nightly, nightly.

div3.p: By request of many citizens, who could not attend before Tuesday night, George Reems will sing and dance "Here's Your Mule." Be sure and come early to secure seats.
For particulars, see bills of the day.

Birch's Brass Band
in front of the Hall nightly.
Come early to secure a good seat.
On Thursday Evening a Hunting-Case Gold Watch will be given to the person that has the ticket that will match the one that is drawn from the hat.

Dan Howard, the celebrated Slack-Rope Performer, is engaged, and will shortly appear.
Due notice will be given of his first appearance.

div3.head:
Richmond Varieties,
(Franklin street, next to Exchange Hotel.)
div3.p: Monday Evening, September 12, 1864.

Unequalled success of the renowned
Olio Minstrels.
Double Attraction!

First appearance of the Female Minstrels.
Miss. Clara Dean, Bones; Miss. Lolie Devrer, Tamborine; Miss. Katie Fisher, Violin; Miss. Frank Rand, Banjo; Miss. Alice Dean, Guitar; Miss. Ruth Daniels, Violoncello; Mrs. Banks, Leading Violin.
Miss. Inez Floyd in a New Ballad.
Harry Allen, R. Jean Buckley, Charley White, Billy Pell, Billy Lewis and Charley Harris, appear in new Commonalities.
Glorious Bill to-night.
Mons. Howard, the Slack-Rope Performer, will shortly appear.
See small bills.

div3.head: Moonlight Excursion.
div3.p:
The Steamer William Allison will make a Moonlight Excursion down James river
On Tuesday Next, 13th instant,
leaving the wharf at half-past 7 o'clock; returning to the city at 12 o'clock.
The Armory Band (Professor Lœbman) is engaged for the occasion.
Refreshments will be found on the boat.
Fare for the Trip: Gentlemen, $10; gentleman and lady, $10, and each additional lady, $5; children under ten years of age, $2.50.

div3.head: Grand Select Ball.
div3.p: A Grand Select Ball will be given at the Monticello Hall

On Monday Evening, September 12, 1864; on which occasion the Managers pledge themselves to use every possible effort to make it the most pleasant and agreeable affair of the kind that has been given in Richmond for years.
Grand Entree March at 9 o'clock precisely.
A splendid Cotillon Band has been engaged.
Strict order will be enforced.
Tickets, admitting a gentleman and ladies, $5.

a Grand Ball will be given at the New Market Hall,
(corner of Sixth and Marshall streets,)
on Monday Evening next, September 12, 1864.
Grand March to commence precisely at 9 o'clock P. M. Music by Professor Tremer's Cotillon Band.
no pains will be spared to make this one of the most pleasant parties of the season.
Tickets, admitting a gentleman and ladies, $5.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
The Grand Select Ball which was to be given at Company G's Hall on Thursday, September 8th, for the benefit of Jasper Meredith, is postponed until
Tuesday Evening, September 13th,
on account of the inclemency of the weather.
Tickets heretofore sold will be good on Tuesday evening next.
A good time will be insured to all who may attend it.
Groceries, Wines, Liquors, &c., for sale by W. F. Price, Thirteenth street, between Main and Cary, Richmond, Virginia.

Seven hundred Pads Cotton Yarns, Nos. 6 to 14,
200 pairs Cotton and Wool Cards,
5,000 yards 4-4 Brown Cotton,
New Orleans Molasses, (genuine,)
Spirits Turpentine,
Tobacco, Sugar, &c.,
For sale, wholesale and retail, at
div3.closer:
Bosher & Wooddy's,
No. 71 Main street. se 8--6t*

div3.p: Late Arrivals at Belvin's Block Shoe Store.
Store on Twelfth street, above Main.
List of Letters remaining in the Richmond Post-Office on the 9th day of September, 1864.
Persons calling for Letters in the List will please say they are Advertised.
the postage will be two Cents on each letter Advertised.

div3.p:
The Daily Dispatch is sold to News Dealers at Twenty Cents per copy.
City carriers are authorized to charge one Dollar and fifty Cents per week to regular subscribers.

div3.head: The War News.
div3.p:
There were sundry rumors in circulation yesterday as to the situation of affairs at Petersburg; but being unconfirmed by official intelligence, we place no confidence in them.
On Friday, about one o'clock P. M., a brisk cannonade commenced on the left of our lines, which gradually extended around to the centre, and eventually reached the right.
Towards two o'clock the firing increased in rapidity, and until three the roar of artillery was uninterrupted.
While this cannonade was going on the enemy shelled the city vigorously, throwing upwards of a hundred destructive missiles within the corporate limits.
The result was some damage to property, but no personal injury was sustained.
A deserter reports that Grant has issued orders to one or more corps to supply themselves with three days cooked rations, and intimates that some new movement is on foot.
It is conjectured that he has an eye to cutting the Southside railroad; but it is hoped that our military authorities are prepared for any move of that sort.
It is considered reliable that Grant is receiving reinforcements, as within the last few days transports have been seen coming up the river laden with troops.
Appearances indicate that there will soon be a revival of active operations in front of Petersburg.

On Friday night the enemy attacked a portion of the picket line and took some prisoners, causing the pickets to fall back.
On Saturday morning fifty-nine Yankees were captured; but our original picket line was not re-established on Saturday evening.

div4.head: Latest from Petersburg.
div4.p:
Passengers by last evening's train reported everything quiet in front.
There was no change in the general situation.
It is stated that our original picket line has been re-established.

div4.head: The Northern Border.
div4.p:
The latest accounts we have from the Valley of Virginia are furnished by the Northern papers of the 7th.
The Yankees seem to have come to the conclusion that General Early has no idea of retreating, and the prospect is that Sheridan will have some heavy work to perform yet.

div4.head: From Georgia.
div4.p:
Late advices represent that the enemy is closely massed around Atlanta, and that there is no prospect of an advance soon.
In their retreat from Jonesboro', the Yankees destroyed fifteen miles of the Macon and Western railway.
Our picket line now extends six miles beyond Jonesboro', with no enemy in sight except scattered parties.
The following dispatch has been received from General Hood:

div5.p:
General Sherman has ordered the removal of all citizens from Atlanta, to go North or South, as they may elect, and proposes a truce for ten days to provide for the transportation of such as may desire to come South.
I have accepted, and am making arrangements.

Prisoners report that thirty thousand of Sherman's troops will be mustered out of service this month, and that the term of many of them expired before the fall of Atlanta, but they were induced to remain until after that event.

div4.head: Wheeler's report of his operations.
div4.p: The following official dispatch was received yesterday:

div5.p: The following dispatch has just been received from Major-General Wheeler, dated at a point between Lawrenceburg, Tennessee, and Athens, Alabama, 6th instant, via Corinth and Mobile on the 9th instant:

"'We destroyed the railroad and bridges on the Nashville railroad, and then worked down on the Alabama and Tennessee railroad.
We destroyed fifty miles of the Tennessee railroad, and also several trains and much property.
In every fight, thus far, with the enemy we have been successful, capturing and damaging a large number.
Our loss is about one hundred killed and wounded. No prisoners have been captured from us in action.'

div3.p: Governor Brown, of Georgia, has set apart the 15th day of September as a day of fasting and prayer.
The not earnings of the Virginia and Tennessee railroad for the year ending June 30th were $1,777,551.32.
Colonel Robert W. Withers, of the Forty-fifth Virginia regiment, was badly wounded at or near Shepherdstown recently — shot through the lungs.

div4.head:
Army of Northern Virginia,
near Petersburg, Va., September 10, 1864.
div4.p:
Atlanta has fallen; Forts Powell, Morgan and Gaines have been surrendered into the hands of the enemy, and Jack Morgan is dead.
Truly, misfortunes never come alone.
But super-add to these reverses the rejoicing which rescind throughout the entire North, and bear in mind that the enemy announce large accretions to their military numbers, and you have the military situation.

The month of September will likely witness no grand military effort, either on the Virginia or Georgia military chess-board.
Grant and Sherman are, meanwhile, not idle.
Their camps are busy in preparation; and, backed by the authorities at Washington, they are making ready to deal us hard knocks by the "early" frost Fous est abhorte deceri is a motto worthy to be remembered and acted upon.
If the enemy are engaged in gigantic preparations for our overthrow, it behooves as to be girding on our armor and marshaling on hosts to meet them.

The Army of Northern Virginia Deeds reinforcement to its fighting materiel. The reinforcement must come at once!
Can the Government get them?
I answer yes. In the first place, there are to-day not less than five thousand able-bodied detailed men in the quartermaster, commissary, medical and ordnance departments of this army, whose places can be supplied by negroes and, disabled men — the negroes to fill such places as teamsters and drivers, and disabled men the position of clerks and messengers.
Many of these men, from favoritism or other causes, have been kept out of service for years, if, indeed, they have ever shouldered arms.
Let General Lee and Secretary Seddon will it, and these men can be under arms and acting as good soldiers in ten days. Again, there are men detailed for useless and evasive duty all over the State.
Let these be returned.
I hear it said that forty thousand names on the muster rolls of the Army of Northern Virginia have opposite their respective names the simple word "detailed." Again, the State of Georgia, with a readiness that does her credit, has called her reserves to the front.
If the States of Virginia, North Carolina and South Carolina, will just now imitate her example, Hood and Lee can both receive in this way valuable and appreciable reinforcements.
Let them be called for at once.
Ere thirty days shall have elapsed Grant will receive his drafted or volunteer men. All that Grant expects them to do is to man his already almost impregnable breastworks, whilst his old troops are disengaged for work on the flanks.
Shall General Lee be reinforced by men, or shall this army, worn with the fatigue and exhaustion of a long and bloody conflict, be forced, in the hour of its triumph, to lose the price of victory by a lack of men?
Some of the papers are calling for Congress and the Legislature to assemble.
If it is meant for them to assemble in Richmond to take up arms and march to the front, I say brave! If they are expected to meet there to talk and legislate, I say no. There is already legislation enough.
Let the laws be executed.
The President has power enough.--Let the "justice, equity and necessity" exemptions be curtailed, as well as those of the agricultural classes — all of which emanate directly from the War Office--and we shall have men enough and to spare.
It is not necessary to rob the States of their judges, clerks and sheriffs to fill the armies.
It is not necessary to destroy States' rights.
The material for recruiting the arms-bearing soldiers is in the army and under control of the War Office. The men can be furnished in ten days if Secretary Seddon determines that it shall be done.

Let not our authorities and our newspaper press lay the flattering unction to their hearts that victories can be achieved without men; nor that other delusion, which is inevitable on the heels of each disaster, that the people are always at fault and skulking.
The Government is not a myth, but a real, tangible entity, and is clothed with the power to recruit the armies.
Will they do it, as they have done before, by the impartial exercise of the powers and trusts confided by the representatives of the people?

Now is the accepted time--let there be no delay.
The teamsters, cooks, ambulance-drivers, clerks, and other detailed men, can reinforce General Lee five thousand men. Why should the authorities refuse the brave men in the trenches the companionship and support of such obvious and necessary reinforcements?
The reserves are within ten days call — no need of an extra session and new legislation.
The men are at hand — all that is needed is the order, so strangely withheld, for them to fall in. If we delay till frost, or for new legislation, the events of the interval may supersede the necessity of legislation.
But new grants of power are unnecessary.
Execute the laws, and all will be well. --Perhaps this communication may fall without fruit.
If its suggestions are heeded, the country will be benefitted; if ignored, I will not answer for results.
Reinforce Lee and Hood are the suggestions of prudence and common sense, which I cannot suppose our authorities will willfully disregard.

The enemy have nearly finished their branch of the City Point road to the Weldon railroad; and everything indicates a purpose — so soon as they are strong enough — to make a bold effort to seize the Southside railroad.

This morning, about 3 o'clock, the enemy massed eleven skeleton regiments in front of Finnegan and Harris's skirmish lines, driving them in from two lines and capturing some thirty or forty prisoners. Finnegan quickly rallied his skirmishers, retaking the second or inner line, and re-establishing his pickets at that point.
Our line is now receded about two hundred yards in some places, but not more than fifty yards in other places, of what it was on yesterday.
There was considerable cannonading during this little affair; but all is quiet at this writing.

div3.p: We give below some additional extracts from Northern papers of the 7th:
A dispatch from Washington of the 6th says.

q.p: It is assorted here, in well-informed Republican circles, that General Fremont will withdraw his name from the presidential contest within ten days. It is also stated that Hon. B. F. Wade is shortly to take the stump for the Baltimore nominees.

div3.p: The Georgia capture is thus settled by a Washington telegram:

q.p:
The seizure of the late rebel pirate steamer Georgia, by the United States steamer Niagara, was made in accordance with the well-established principle of English maritime law, that belligerent vessels cannot, during the continuance of hostilities, be legally transferred, as regards ownership, in neutral ports, and are liable to seizure wherever found, notwithstanding they may have been actually and in good faith sold to neutral parties.
The same principle of maritime law has been declared by this Government, and under it any vessel that has been used for belligerent purposes, under the authority of the so-called Confederate Government, will be seized whenever it can be done, whatever may be her actual ownership at the time.
The English Government has recently re-asserted this law, and issued instructions forbidding the transfer of such vessels in British waters; and there is no chance for any complication to arise from such seizures, it only being necessary to identify the vessel to render its seizure legal and valid.

div3.p:
The newest dodge now in Yankee land is to represent the enlistments as very rapid and heavy.
A dispatch says:

q.p:
During the last ten days the number of men mustered into the army has averaged three thousand a day. On the 2d instant four thousand one hundred and thirty-six were mustered in, and on the 3d six thousand one hundred and sixty.
These are the latest reports received.
The number mustered in on the 3d instant is probably greater than has been mustered in during any other one day for nearly two years.

div3.head: Notice.--Estray Horse.
div3.p:
--Came to my farm, on the Darbytown road, in Henrico county, on the 3d day of September, 1864, a Bay Horse, about sixteen hands high, Roman face, and a scar on his left shoulder.
The owner will please come forward, pay charges, and take him away.

div3.head: Destructive fire in Manchester — over three Million dollars' worth of property destroyed.
div3.p:
--One of the most destructive fires which has ever occurred in this State took place in Manchester on Friday night last.
About 12 o'clock, the citizens in the neighborhood were aroused by the roaring of the flames, which proceeded from the northwestern wing of the Messrs.
Gary's tobacco factory, situated on Barney street, between Allen and Bainbridge, and in an incredibly short time the whole building was in a light blaze.
The wind setting in a favorable direction, the large tobacco warehouse, on the opposite side of the street, owned by Messrs, John Gilmour & Co., soon took fire, and despite the efforts of a number of citizens to put it out, the destructive elements traveled from one section of the vast structure to the other till the whole of it was entirely consumed.

When the last portion of this warehouse and all the various buildings inside of the enclosure were levelled to the ground, the wind suddenly changed to the northwest, and carried the flames in the direction where the fire originated, communicating them with the fine family residence of Mrs. Ophelia Fuqus, a widow lady, on the corner of Bainbridge and Barney streets, and from thence spreading to her kitchen in the yard, Mrs. Susan P. Allen's kitchen on the next lot, and another building adjacent, in the occupancy of the Messrs.
Gary, owned by William Gray, of this city, resulting in the total destruction of them all. In addition to these buildings, which were destroyed, the residences of F. W. Redford, Patrick Gary, Mrs. Susan P. Allen, and the large framed tenement used as negro quarters for the Manchester cotton factory, took fire several times, and were considerably damaged.

The buildings known as Gilmour's tobacco warehouse covered a whole square, fronting on Bainbridge street, all of which were enclosed by a brick wall.
Inside of these were burnt up six hundred and seventy hogsheads of fine stripped tobacco, four hundred hogsheads of leaf tobacco, three hundred hogsheads of stemmed tobacco, which were the property of Gilmour & Co., and two hundred and thirty-four hogsheads of leaf tobacco, the property of the Confederate States.
The aggregate cost of the tobacco destroyed, belonging to Gilmour & Co., amounted to £35,000 before the war, which, estimated at the present value of exchange, will exceed the sum of $3,000,000. On this there was an insurance of $224,000, held altogether in Southern companies.
Add to the above amount the loss of the warehouse buildings and that used as a factory by the Gary brothers, also owned by Gilmour & Co., and the loss will be increased to upwards of two hundred thousand dollars more.
Upon the buildings was a nominal insurance.
The senior partner of the concern, Mr. John Gilmour, left this country for Scotland (of which he is a native) in the year 1859, where he has resided over since.
During his absence the business of the firm has been attended to by a young man bearing the same name, who is a relative.

The Messrs.
Gary, the proprietors of the tobacco factory in which the fire was first discovered, lost upwards of one hundred thousand dollars' worth of tobacco, (a large portion of which was manufactured,) tobacco presses, screws, frames, &c., on which they had an insurance of $25,000.
About $50,000 will probably cover the whole loss of property owned by Mrs. Fuqus, Mrs. Allen, William Gray and others, on which we have heard of no insurance.

On account of the low state of water in the river, and the limited supply which could be pumped into the Manchester reservoir, no assistance could be rendered by the fire engines.
The Richmond fire companies, as soon as the alarm was given, buried to the foot of Mayo's bridge, where they awaited the return of Chief-Engineer Barnes, who went over to ascertain to what extent the department there could be assisted.
In a short time Mr. Barnes came back and ordered company B.
and the Hook and Ladder company to hasten to the scene, but the stream which the reservoir afforded was so feeble that it soon became manifest that the fire was not to be extinguished with water.

This fire, which was without doubt the work of an incendiary, lit up the whole heavens for upwards of five hours, and at a late hour yesterday afternoon its entire area was still in a blaze from the burning rubbish and smouldering tobacco scattered around.

Fortunately no very serious accident occurred, although Mr. Ajax Gary was compelled to jump from a second-story window, and made a narrow escape while under it from having a box of tobacco thrown on him.

div3.head: Robbery.
div3.p:
--Saturday night, while a gentleman was purchasing a ticket of admission to the theatre, some adroit thief among the crowd which was standing around, stole from his vest pocket a superior gold watch and chain.
The button-hole of his vest, to which the hook of the chain was attached, was nicely cut in two, as if it had been done with a sharp instrument.

div3.head: The alarm of fire Saturday night.
div3.p: --The alarm of fire which took place about half-past 11 o'clock on Saturday night proceeded from the partial burning of a framed building on Seventeenth street, in the occupancy of William Jones, formerly of the firm of Brown, Peasley & Co. Before the arrival of the fire engines, the flames were extinguished by persons in the neighborhood, with the assistance of Lieutenant Baptist, of the night police.

div3.head: To be sent North.
div3.p:
--Upwards of three hundred wounded and sick Yankee prisoners will be sent North this morning by flag-of-truce boat.
Among the number will be included Captain Ives and Lieutenant Gœsber, who have been selected as hostages in exchange for Confederate prisoners North, and Captain Sloman.

div3.head: Arrest.
div3.p: --Nicholas Carroll, keeper of a restaurant on Main street, was arrested on Saturday afternoon on the charge of defrauding Mrs. Julia A. Farriss out of $170. The matter will be investigated this morning.

div3.head: Captured by negroes.
div3.p:
--A negro man belonging to Mr. Thomas H. Wynne, who has been a runaway for some time, was captured in Chesterfield a few nights since by three servants belonging to Mr. William Burton of that county.
The runaway was in an old deserted tobacco barn roasting green corn for his supper, when he was suddenly pounced upon by his captors and confined.

div3.head: State Arms.
div3.p: --As will be seen by an advertisement in this paper, the Adjutant-General of the State calls on all persons having in their possession arms and accoutrements, the property of the State, and not using them as members of some military organization of the State, to deliver them as speedily as possible to Captain P. G. Coghlan, the officer in charge of the State Armory, corner Seventh and Cary streets, in this city.

We hope this call will be cheerfully and readily obeyed.
It is important that it should be — in fact, persons neglecting to comply will render themselves liable to legal penalty, as each and every individual holding such arms and accoutrements is personally responsible for their full value to the State Department, from which they been received.

div3.head: Fine markets.
div3.p: --The recent refreshing ruins which we have had has much advanced the growth of vegetables, and as a consequence our markets have been well supplied for several days past. --Prices have also somewhat fallen.

div3.head: From Georgia.
div3.p: --The Yankees completely destroyed the railroad between Jonesboro' and East Point in their retreat, burning every tie and breaking every rail.

The prisoners captured yesterday say Sherman will now reinforce Grant, take Richmond, and finish the rebellion.
They also state that one-half of his army will go out of service this month.
Our pickets extend six miles beyond Jonesboro'
The enemy are closely massed about Atlanta.--There is not the slightest prospect of an early resumption of hostilities.

div4.head: [second Dispatch.]
div4.p: --The Chattanooga Gazette of the 6th instant says that Wheeler's forces have been dispersed, near Tullahoma, by Steadman.

div3.head: From Mobile.
div3.p: --All quiet and without interest below to-day.
Mobile, September 10.--Nothing of interest has transpired below to-day.

The Subscriber, Having Recovered from his late illness, will attend his office from to-day, and will be pleased to see his patients and the public generally.
A splendid assortment of Gold Foil and other materials on hand.
Persons wishing to see me on business, after office hours, will please call at my residence, on Marshall street, between First and Adams.

M. A. Blankman.
Surgeon and Dentist, 82 Main street. se 10--ts

Keeps constantly on hand a general assortment of Groceries, Wines and Liquors, which he is prepared to sell at the lowest market rates.

div3.head: Rags Wanted.
div3.p: --The highest market price will be paid at this Office for all kinds of Clean Cotton and Linen Rags, in large or small quantities.

It is not long since the New York Times published an article setting forth that the capture of Richmond, then confidently anticipated by the Northern public, would have no effect in "crushing the rebellion," unless it was also accompanied by the capture of General Lee's army.
Grant, it was alleged, saw this with great distinctness, and hence had spread his nets in such a way that the army, which is the real capital of the rebellion, should not escape.

It need not be said that even Richmond has not succumbed to Grant, much less the army, which not only bids him defiance, but is numerically as strong as when Grant first crossed the Rapidan.
It is the truth enunciated by the Times; i. e., that the fall of this Confederate stronghold or that does not affect the vital energies of our defence so long as the great armies of the Confederacy remain intact.
It is this that should engage the serious reflection of the people of the United States.
They are just now in a state of absurd elation over the fall of Atlanta; but the fall of Atlanta, they ought never to forget, did not involve the fate of General Hood's army — an army as large as that with which General Lee now confronts the enemy in Virginia.
On the contrary, General Sherman is unable to advance at present; and his success is only one of those indecisive successes which have characterized this war on both sides from the beginning.
Whether it can be called a success at all is problematical, and remains to be determined by future events.

There is food for reflection to the Northern people in these things.
They are promised now, as they have been promised all along, a speedy termination of the war. What reason have they to put confidence in such promises!
What have they accomplished with the million and a half of men they have already raised?
Not even the capture of Richmond, which is a mere outpost of our immense territory, and which the Times confesses would not, if taken, affect the strength of the rebellion.
Scott, McClellan, Burnside, Hooker, Grant, have each successively hurled immense armies upon our capital, and have been beaten back as the sea-girl rock beats back the ocean waves in empty froth and foam Gunboats by water, and raid after raid by land, have been signally foiled.
The hand of Providence has been plainly interposed in our behalf.
And what if the North does raise more men?
They will still find us in "overwhelming numbers," and with new and more powerful fortifications.
And then, even supposing them to take Richmond, after an expenditure of life which will clothe every household in the North in mourning, their work will be but just begun.
We can fight out this war, as President Davis truly said long ago, twenty years in Virginia before it will become necessary to fall back upon North Carolina.
The Black Republicans of this generation will have gone to their own place before the work of our subjugation is accomplished.

The history of the invasion thus far shows that the conquest of our territory, even where it is effected, extends no farther than the spot in actual occupation by the Federal armies.
A great part of it once held by them has become our own again.
The great State of Texas has scarcely a Yankee upon its soil.
The same may be said of a large portion of Louisiana, Arkansas, and even Tennessee.
The Mississippi did not become a free river with the fall of Vicksburg.
The advance of the invading army has been likened to a ship, which can call no place its own upon the ocean except that beneath its keel.
As it goes on, its very track becomes obliterated, and the waves unite again and rage angrily behind it. This invasion, more than any of modern times, makes its most implacable enemies wherever its armies penetrate.
If they observed the rules of civilized warfare, the effect might be different; but robbery and house-burning, the universal law of this invasion, supply an irritant which kindles the most lukewarm patriotism into a flame of eternal hate.
The consequence is, that the Federal troops must not expect to hold, occupy and possess anything of this land but what their feet stand on. And unless the foot of each man is as big as that of Lincoln, we can easily spare for the next fifty years the few acres of territory they hold.

When, therefore, the usurper at Washington promises that this new draft will end the war, he is only promising what he does not himself believe he is able to perform.
What reason has the North to believe this more than any of his former promises?
Can they be so stupid after all their experience as to believe that this is to be his last draft!
We are not given to prophesying, but we think it would be much safer to predict that next year will see a call for another half million, than that the South will be subjugated.
Moreover, if he cannot conquer us before November, and even he has not the impudence to venture that assertion, he will make no serious effort to accomplish it during the remainder of his Presidential term.
He will keep the war up if he can for the benefit of his party, and bring into the field occasionally numbers large enough to prolong, but not large enough to decide it. The North may expect to be harassed by successive drafts as long as Lincoln is in the Presidential chair; but he cannot, if he would, make drafts large enough to conquer the Confederacy and establish peace.

He has undertaken, in his own choice vernacular, "a big job," and the magnitude of it, instead of diminishing, is increasing every day. For ourselves, we acknowledge that we want peace, but we see that we are not to have it except at the price of independence, which, incredible as it may seem to ignoble minds, is dearer to a high-spirited people than peace with all its blessings.

div3.head: Correction of an important Error.
div3.p:
We stated on Saturday that there had been one hundred and fourteen thousand details for agricultural purposes in the Confederacy.
We should have said one hundred and fourteen thousand applications for detail.
Very many of them, we understand, were rejected.

We must not be understood as advocating a general turn out in arms of the whole agricultural force.
There must be enough left to supply an abundance of food for the country and the army.
But extreme caution should be observed in granting applications.

div3.head: Seward on the Tripod once more.
div3.p:
Seward is a most indefatigable prophet.
He has demolished the Confederacy in his productions some ten or a dozen times since this war began.
He is trying his hand once again, which we hold to be favorable to our cause, since his prophecies are always to be interpreted by contraries.
It is no longer, however, "ninety days after date." Probably no man ever made so many false prophecies as Seward.

div4.p: On the 1st instant, at the residence of the bride's father, by the Rev. James C. Councill, Charles C. C. Adams, of Baltimore, Maryland, to Miss Sallie E. Hudgins, of Mathews county, Virginia.

In Portsmouth, Virginia, on the 2d of September, 1864, of typhoid fever, Carrol Foster, youngest son of Amelia B. and Robert T. K. Balu, aged two years and eight months.
On Friday, the 9th instant, about 10 o'clock A. M., after a lingering and painful illness, which she bore with Christian resignation, Mrs. Ann Anderson, in the sixty-eighth year of her age.

lg.l: Take this new treasure to thy trust;
And give these sacred relies room
To slumber in the silent dust."

div4.p: On the afternoon of the 10th instant, of diphtheria and whooping-cough, Willits B., son of John B. and Judith A. Crenshaw, aged two years, eight months and twenty-five days.
His funeral will take place from his father's residence to-day at 10 o'clock A. M. The friends and relatives are invited to attend without further notice.

--Ballard-House Sale.--All parties who have bought any articles at my sale are very urgently requested to call promptly and get their purchases.
The accounts are all ready, and it is very desirable to get the rooms emptied as soon as possible.

div3.head:
French language.
Monsieur Louis Ganbin.
div3.p: Professor of French,

would respectfully inform the Principals of Schools in this city that on Monday, the 26th instant, he will resume the duties of his profession.
He will also give private instructions either at the pupil's residence or at his own. His system of teaching the language is to enable his scholars to converse in French as well as to translate.
Satisfactory references will be furnished if desired.
Those wishing to secure his services for the coming session will please direct a note to him through the post-office as soon as convenient.
His terms will be moderate.

Mrs. M. H. Chappell, Having opened a School for girls and small boys at the Bellevue House, on Broad street, between Twentieth and Twenty-first streets, will thankfully receive any patronage that may be extended to her. The usual English branches, with Music and French, will be taught.
Terms made known on application.

--The exercises of our school will be resumed on the Third of October.
For terms, &c., apply at the school building, corner of Grace and Foushee streets.

Mr. Turner can be seen at his residence, on Third street, between Main and Franklin.

For further information, apply at the residence of Mrs. John P. Hill, on the south side of Clay, one door from Seventh street.

Terms: For the first quarter, (in advance,) $100.
I am authorized, both by exemption from Confederate and by special detail from State duty, for the purpose of continuing my School, to say that its exercises will not be interrupted.

div3.head: Select School For boys,
div3.p: Franklin street, between Sixth and Seventh.
R. H. L. Tighe, A. M., Principal.
Louis Ganbin, Teacher of French.
The Twelfth Annual Session of this School will open on Monday, the 26th instant, and end in July, 1865.

The Principal is not liable to Confederate service, and is detailed from State service to attend to the duties of his school.
His patrons and friends have, therefore, this assurance that his school will be conducted without interruption.
For further information and entrance of pupils apply at school-room from 2 to 3 o'clock P. M., or at his residence, on Main street, Sidney.

div3.head: Kalorama family School, Staunton, Virginia.
div3.p: --This school will be re-opened on the first Monday in October for a session of nine months.
Terms, for half session, ending February 15, 1865:

row.cell:
payable in family supplies at the rates specified in the Circular; or, in cases where this is not practicable, the equivalent thereof in current funds.
Tuition in English

div3.p: Washing and Lights, extra.
Address
Mrs. Hanson, or Miss Sheffey,
Staunton, Virginia.
N. B.--Persons applying are requested to state the ages of pupils.

div3.head:
L. S. Squire's.
Select Classical
and English School,
corner of Main and First streets.
div3.p: The Eighteenth Session will commence on the 26th of September, 1864.
The Principal is not liable to military duty.
Persons wishing to see him can leave a note at Grant's Commission House, corner of Main and First streets.

div3.head: Edgewood Male seminary.
div3.p:
--The next session of this School will commence the first Monday in October next and end the 15th of February.
For terms, apply to the subscriber, at Amelia Courthouse, Virginia.
Mrs. Eliza J. Pleasants will resume the duties of her School, on Church Hill, on Monday, the 3d of October.

div3.head: Miss. Lucy King's School For Young Ladies.
div3.p:
--Miss. King will resume the duties of her School on the first Monday in October.
For further particulars, apply to Miss. L. King, second door from the corner of Broad and Mayo streets.

div3.head: Information.
div3.p:
--Persons who have lost the location of McPHERSON can find him always ready to oblige the wants of his old army friends, and their friends, too, at Congress Hall, next to the Main Street Telegraph office.
Strangers will find him a generous host, as did myself.
Just received at 205 Broad street, between Fourth and Fifth,

list.item: 100 dozen Pocket Knives, Pocket Combs and Pocket Books,
200 groes Knitting Pins, Thimbles and Tooth Brushes,
150 dozen Hair Brushes and Dressing Combs,
150 sets Knives and Forks and Plated Tea and Table Spoons,
Hair Brooms, Mill Brushes, Dust Brushes,
Fenders, Shovels and Tongs, Tinware, &c., with our usual assortment of Crockery, such as Cups and Sancers, Ewers and Basins, Plates, &c.

205 Broad street,

div3.p:
Wanted, A House on Shockoe Hill, to contain from seven to ten rooms, with water and gas. Possession to be given (at the convenience of the owner) at any time within the next two months. Any one having such a house can rent it to a careful and responsible tenant, who is an old resident of this city.
Address "Old Citizen," Box 173 Post-office.
Wanted, two or three competent Milliners, to whom the highest wages will be paid.
Just received a lot of superior Velvets and other Millinery and Dry Goods, which the ladies are invited to call and see.
div3.closer:

No. 218 Broad street. se 12--8t

div3.p:

Wanted, two Boiler Makers, at the Manassas Gap Railroad Shops, Greensboro', North Carolina.

Board, one hundred and sixty dollars a month.

div3.p:
Plenty of work and good wages.
Apply to

She will accept a place as saleswoman in a store, or any employment whereby she may gain an honest livelihood.
Address "E," at Dispatch office.

Wanted, A Reliable man, who is exempt from all military service, to act as watchman on a farm near the city.
Best of references required.
To such a one good wages will be paid.
Address Box 739 Richmond Post-office.

div3.p:
Wanted to Rent, A House having six to eight rooms, with all improvements.
Possession to be given on the 1st of January, 1865.
Address Post-office Box 728, giving particulars and price.

Wanted, a well-qualified Governess, to instruct three pupils, in a private family, residing in a retired part of the country, English, French, and Music on the Piano, are indispensable qualifications; a knowledge of Vocal Music and Painting is desirable.
Address "M. K.," Box 825, Richmond, Virginia.

Wanted, by a young man (exempt from military service), thoroughly conversant with business, a Situation as Book Keeper or Clerk in some established Banking or Mercantile House.
Any required reference can be given.
Address "J. H. S.," Box 290, Richmond Post-office.

div3.head: Wanted, a House.
div3.p: --Any person having a House to rent, either furnished or unfurnished, can hear of a desirable tenant by adddressing a note to Box No. 1,063 City Post-office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Maple, Beech, Birch, and Persimmon Blocks, fourteen inches long, ten inches and larger, in diameter.
We are prepared to fill orders for Shoe Lasts, Boot Trees, Crimping Boards, &c., of all sizes and styles.
div3.closer:
Mercer & Hill,
Seventh and Canal streets. se 9--3t

div3.head: A good Cook Wanted.
div3.p:
--I want to hire, for the balance of the year, a good Cook.
Inquire at corner Sixth and Franklin streets.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--I wish to purchase good Scrap Iron, Old Tires, Grates, short Bars, such as will make horse shoes.
For all such I will pay more than market price.
Apply at the corner of Seventeenth and Franklin streets, at Ellison's.

Wanted, by a Virginia lady, a graduate of the Richmond Female Institute, of three years experience, a situation as Teacher in a private family.
Competent to instruct in higher English, French and Music.
References exchanged.
Address, stating terms, L. B. B., Box 299, Richmond, Virginia.

Shoemakers Wanted to work upon Ladies' work.
The highest cash prices paid.
Apply at Belvin's Block Shoe Store.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A gentleman or lady, who has had experience in teaching, and who is qualified to teach the English branches, Latin, and especially French, can hear of a good Situation in a private family by addressing Mrs. L., at this office.

div3.head: A Female Teacher Wanted.
div3.p: --I should be pleased to engage the services of an experienced Female Teacher of Latin, French, highest English Branches, and Music on the Piano, to take charge of a small school of young ladies at my house, two miles from Scottsville, in Albemarle county, Virginia, to commence about the 1st September or 1st of October, for ten months.
References given and desired.
Address, with terms, &c., immediately,

Wanted to Rent, a House, suitable for a small family, or two or three Rooms, in a private family, with the use of kitchen.
Satisfactory references given.
Address "M.," General Ewell's Headquarters, giving name and place.

Wanted a situation, by a single man, exempt from military service, as Manager on A Farm, to go anywhere in the Confederate States.
Refers to Charles Phillips, corner of Ninth and Main streets, or to
div3.closer:
James H. Smith,
One mile below Richmond.
Postscript.--I will also attend to any other kind of business. se 5--M&W4t

div3.p: Wanted, Broom Corn, for which the highest market price will be paid, in large or small quantities, at our Broom Factory, corner Grace and Twentieth streets.

Wanted, a Female Teacher to take charge of a small school in my family, at Orange Courthouse — a lady well qualified to teach the English branches thoroughly, Latin, French and Music.
Address
div3.closer:
A. Thomson,
Orange Courthouse, Virginia. au 25--1m

div3.head:
Richmond and Danville railroad,
Superintendent's Office,
Richmond, August 15, 1864.
div3.p: On and After Tuesday, August, 16, 1864, the Evening Train on this road, leaving Richmond at 4 P. M., will be devoted exclusively to the transportation of sick and wounded soldiers, and no other persons will be allowed on the train until all the soldiers are comfortably accommodated.
div3.closer:
Charles G. Talcott,
Superintendent. au 24--ts

div3.head:
Adjutant-General's Office, Virginia,
September 8, 1864.
div3.p: State Arms.--All persons having in their possession Arms and Accoutrements, the property of the State, and not using them as members of some military organization of the State, will deliver them as speedily as possible to the officer in charge of the State Armory.
div3.closer:
By command.
William H. Richardson,
Adjutant-General. se 9--3t

Orleans Molasses, Tanners' Oil, White Grease, Old Dominion Nails, assorted; Fencing Nails, Plow-line Rope, Cotton Yarns, Sole and Upper Leather, Scrap Leather, Shelled Oats, Corn, Cotton Cards, Spirits Turpentine and Naptha, Plaid Domestics, Cigars, Manufactured and smoking Tobacco, Shoes, Calfskins, Wrapping Paper, &c., on consignment and for sale by
div3.closer:

Corner of Cary and Thirteenth streets. se 8--4t

div3.head: Fine Tobaccos.
div3.p: --We have for sale 100 boxes fine Chewing Tobacco, of various brands-- "Stultz," "Pace Premium," "Rogers's Gold Leaf," &c.
5,000 pounds Smoking Tobacco--"Regalia," "Deucalion," "Pioneer," and other desirable brands.
div3.closer:
Slaughter & Co.,
159 Main street. se 6--6t

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:
--On Saturday morning last, supposed to be on Fourteenth street, a Leather Fort Monnaie, with gum elastic fastening.
In it were two checks, Nos. 254 and 255, on Exchange Bank, drawn by G. Scott; executrix of James Scott, deceased by James A. Scott, attorney, some other papers of no value save to the owner, and a few half-dollar notes.
A suitable reward will be paid for the wallet and contents if left at Dispatch office.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from my father's, in Henrico county, on last Monday, the 5th instant, a Roan Steer, about two years old. The mark was a fork in each car, and an undersell in the right.
I will give the above reward for any information that will enable me to get him.
div3.closer:
Thomas M. Dettrick,
Henrico county. se 10--3t

div3.p: Stolen, on Monday, the 5th instant, from before General Brang's office, a small Bay Mare, marked "C. S." on shoulder, and hipped in the left hind leg. Any intelligence concerning the Mare or the thief will be thankfully received at the Surgeon general's office by

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p: --Stolen from the stable of Mr. Joseph Coats, Louisa county, Virginia, on the night of the 6th instant, my huge gray Horse, six years old; has a sore on the wither, just at the joint of the Mobile, has a very thin and short tail and a short mane; no foretop; on the left shoulder is branded "U. S.," and just above the U. S. is a large A. I will pay the above reward for the delivery of the horse at Mr. Johnson's stable, on Franklin street, or for any information leading to his recovery.
div3.closer:
Clayton Walker,
Company D, Third Virginia cavalry. se 9--3t

div3.head: Five hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed or stolen from my pasture, near Mr. Valentine's mill and Mr. John B. Smith's shop, Louisa county, Virginia, on the night of the 10th instant, my large bay Horse.
He is about seven years old, has a star out on the right side of his neck, which can be seen by raising his mane, and some white hair on his right hind foot; also, collar marks on his neck and shoulders.
I will give the above reward for his safe delivery to me, (I live near the above-named places,) or I will pay three hundred dollars for any information which will secure me his recovery.
Address
div3.closer:
J. H. Knighton,
Trevillian's Post-office, Louisa county, Va. au 17--1m

div3.head:
John W. Davies & Sons,
Dealers in Music, Books
and Stationery.
div3.p: No. 188 Main street, Richmond, Va., (P. H. Taylor's old stand,)

where may be found a large and valuable collection of Old Music by eminent masters.
This selection was made before the war by a gentleman of acknowledged musical ability and taste; is probably unrivalled by any stock in the Confederacy; and comprises, in addition to Standard Sonatas, concerted pieces, &c., a general assortment of lighten music, such as
Marches,
Quicksteps,
Waltzes,
Songs, &c.
Organists, Pianists, Vocalists, Teachers, and the lovers of good Music generally, are respectfully and confidently invited to examine this stock.
New Music of the day constantly on hand.
Musical Instruments, Violin and Guitar Strings, with a general assortment of Books and Stationery.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--A liberal reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to E. W. Robinson, constable of Henrico county, of William Frank.
He is charged with attacking me (James A. Tucker) on the highway, near Mechanicsville turnpike, and beating my wife.
Said Frank is a German; of large frame; about four feet ten inches high; round, red face, and short hair.
He is the same man that was arrested upon suspicion of aiding Federal officers to escape from the Libby prison.

div3.head: Sale of damaged Tobacco.
div3.p: --On Thursday, the 15th of September, beginning at 11 o'clock, we will have a large sale, at our factory lot, in Manchester, Virginia, of fine Strips, partially burnt, saved from the late fire.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Always on hand, and for sale, Molasses Barrels, Liquor Barrels, Flour Barrels and Kegs of all kinds and sizes; Buckets, Tubs, &c. Orders can be left at F. Delarue's Grocery, No. 7 Franklin street, or at my Cooper shop, on Seventeenth street, corner of Baldwin, near the Central Railroad Workshops.
Delivered anywhere in the city gratis.

div3.head: Rockbridge Alum Springs.
div3.p:
--In response to many inquiries, we will keep the Springs open throughout this month, but shall certainly close the House on the 1st of October.
Board, $20 per day.
div3.closer:
Frazier & Randolph,
Proprietors. se 7--6t

div3.head: For the Potomac.
div3.p:
--Persons desirous of going to the Potomac, by getting proper passports can secure seats in a pleasant conveyance and at moderate charges.
Apply at 146 Main street, between the hours of 9 and 12 o'clock.

div3.head: A complete set of Blacksmiths' Tools For Sale.
div3.p: --A bargain can be had if early application is made on Seventeenth street, between Broad and Marshall, at the Blacksmith Shop.

Try Leonard's Pills,
Leonard's Pills,
Leonard's Pills.

To be had of all Druggists in Richmond.
Price, $2 per box.

div3.head:
Hats!
Hats! Hats!
div3.p:
--A large assortment of the finest French Hats, Fall style, for sale at retail at wholesale prices at
Guggenheimer & Goldsmith's,
No. 134 Main street.
Spotts & Harvey will sell to all families holding tickets of application for Rice two pounds for each member, when not exceeding twenty-five in number, commencing on Monday, 12th of September.

div3.head: Cotton Yarns.
div3.p: 10 bales superior Cotton Yarns, 6 to 12, just received and for sale by

div3.head: Carriage For Sale.
div3.p: --A neat one horse Carriage, recently put in order.--Price, $1,200. Call at Bosher's Carriage Factory corner Ninth and Main streets.
Persons Having servants Hired at Fifth Division, Winder Hospital, are requested to come forward and collect their hire to the 1st of September.
div3.closer:
S. Meredith,
Surgeon in Charge. se 12--3t

div3.p:
For Sale, on Consignment,
30 bags Winter Oats--
an excellent article for seed.
div3.closer:
R. H. Dibrell,
Shockoe Slip. se 12--3t

div3.head: Piano For Sale privately.
div3.p: --I am requested to sell a very elegant Piano.

div3.head: By Grubbs & Williams, Auctioneers.
div3.p:
Six very Valuable small, Substantially-built Brick Houses, on Clay and Catharine streets, For Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Wednesday, the 14th September, at 4½ o'clock P. M., the property located as above.
The Houses are well built and convenient, containing each four rooms, besides closets, and kitchen, with two rooms, attached to each house.
They have a good front, and ran back the usual depths, and afford a nice little garden spot to each.
There is a good well of water on one of the lots on Clay street for the use of the three houses at that locality.
The houses are rented to monthly tenants.
They are occupied respectively by Mrs. Martin, Mr. Crawford, Mr. Cramp and Mr. Ragland.
Terms: Cash or credit, at the option of the purchaser.

div3.head: Brick House and Lot on Leigh street, beyond Brook Avenue, For Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Immediately after the sale of the property above advertised — say at 5 o'clock P. M.--will be sold at auction, on the premises, the substantially-built Brick House located as above, containing four rooms, and a kitchen with two rooms.
The lot has a front of fifty feet on Leigh street, and runs back the usual depth.
Terms: One-third cash; balance at six and twelve months, with interest; or all cash, at the option of the purchaser.

div3.head: Valuable Farm of five hundred and fifty acres, one Mile from Chester, on the Richmond and Petersburg railroad, For Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 20th of September, at 12 o'clock M., the valuable Farm located as above.
There are one hundred and fifty acres of open land, two hundred in original growth; the balance in second growth, some of it very heavily wooded, and within one and a half miles of Osborne, on the James river.
There is some meadow land.
The improvements are all nearly new and, consist of a two-story House, with seven rooms and store-room; kitchen, laundry, and other servants' houses, smoke-house, large barn, stable for twelve horses, seed-room and carriage house, and a well of excellent water in the yard. --The farm may be visited any day by the Petersburg railroad, or on the day of sale.
Persons may, by taking the morning train to Chester, have time to visit the land, and examine it before the sale, and return the same evening to Richmond or Petersburg.
Possession will be given immediately.
Terms: One-third cash; balance at one and two years, with interest; or all cash, at the option of the purchaser.

div3.head: Five Houses and Lots, and a Number of Building Lots, in Sidney, For Sale at Auction.
div3.p: --On Tuesday, the 13th of September, commencing at 4½ o'clock P. M., will be sold, in the order named below, the following Real Estate, to wit:
A Building Lot at the northeast corner of Cary and Belvidere streets, adjoining the residence of Mr. James H. Oliver, forty by one hundred and eight and a half feet.
Three Brick Tenements in Green's Row, on the Plankroad, nearly opposite the Westham House, and one Brick Tenement on Laurel street, south of the Plankroad.
A beautiful Lot at the southwest corner of Cherry and Cumberland streets, sixty by one hundred and fifty feet, adjoining the property of John and James Turner.

The Bedstead Factory, formerly owned by Thomas Suter, and now rented to the Confederate States as a hospital at one thousand dollars. The Lot is one hundred and twenty by one hundred and thirty-seven feet.
The foregoing property should, by its situation and character, attract persons seeking investment of homes for themselves.
Terms at sale.

div3.head: Valuable Lot on the South line of Broad and Sixteenth streets For Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at public auction, on the premises, on Thursday, September 15, at 4½ o'clock P. M., the Lot located as above.
It has a front of twenty-six feet on Broad, running back eighty-eight feet on Sixteenth street.
Terms: Cash.

div3.head: Immediately After the above
div3.p: sale — say at 5 o'clock--will be sold, at auction, the Lot,--fifty by one hundred and fifty feet.--with framed house and kitchen thereon, on Venable, between Eighteenth and Nineteenth streets, occupied by Mr. William Gennett at a rental of thirty dollars per month.
Terms: Cash.

div3.head: Sale in Manchester.
div3.p:
--Framed House and Lot on Hull street and four Building Lots on Biddle street. On Saturday, 17th September, at half-past 4 o'clock P. M., we will sell, upon the premises, a Framed House and Lot on the west side of Hull (main) street, in Manchester, adjoining Alexander Baxter's store.
The lot is twenty-five and a half by one hundred and forty feet.

Also, four Building Lots at the corner of Biddle and Bainbridge streets, near the Masons' Hall, fronting one hundred and twenty feet, running back one hundred and twenty feet to an alley, and adjoining the property of Mr. Traylor.
Terms: Cash or credit, as the purchasers may prefer.

Executor's Sale of A most Valuable Dwelling and premises at the Southeast corner of Marshall and Eighth streets, and two likely Young Negro men, at Auction, By virtue of the will of C. J. Macmurdo, Jr., dec'd, and at the request of the parties interested, I shall, as Executor, expose to sale, at public auction, upon the premises, on Monday, the 19th day of September, at 4½ o'clock P. M., the Dwelling and premises of the late C. J. Macmurdo, Junior, being lot No. 790 in the plan of the city of Richmond, situated as above stated, fronting one hundred and thirty feet on Marshall street and running back one hundred and sixty-three and four-twelfths feet.
The dwelling is large and handsome, and, both by its construction and location, is the most desirable that has been offered in this city for some time past.
With the dwelling will be sold a Lot, of suitable size; and the remainder of the property will be laid off into several building lots according to a plan which will be shown at the sale.
A perfect title will be given, and possession on the 1st of November.
After the sale of the real estate, will be sold two very likely and valuable Young Negro men, named Robert and William — both of whom are barbers, and accomplished servants.

Terms: For the real estate, one-third cash; balance at four and eight months, with interest, and secured by a trust deed; or all cash, at the option of the purchaser.
For the slaves, cash.
div3.closer:
George P. Macmurdo,
Executor of C. J. Macmurdo, deceased.
Sale conducted by Grubbs & Williams, Auctioneers. se 10

div3.head: By P. W. Grubbs, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
Fine Mattaponi Estate of five hundred and fifty acres, in Caroline county, within one Mile of Milford Depot, and one and A half miles from Bowling Green, called Holly Hill, For Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Thursday, the 15th September, at 11 o'clock A. M., the very valuable estate located as above.
It contains five hundred and fifty acres, of which about three-fourths are open land, and one-fourth in wood and timber.
The open land is in a good state of improvement.
The improvements consist of a large dwelling and every other out-building usually found on such an estate — all in good repair.
The location is beautiful.
There is on the place a very large orchard of peaches and apples of the choicest kinds.--This is a rare opportunity of securing a valuable and most beautiful estate.
Partial possession will be given at once, and full possession so soon as the growing crops can be secured.
The Richmond and Fredericksburg railroad passes through the farm near the house, affording an opportunity of visiting the place and returning the same day.
Terms: One-third cash; balance at six and twelve months; or all cash, at the option of the purchaser.

div3.head: By Redwood, Phillips & Co., Auctioneers.
div3.p:
We will Sell at Auction on Thursday Next, the 16th of September, at 4 o'clock P. M., that excellent little Farm situated in the county of Henrico two miles from the city of Richmond, on the Meadow Bridge road, known as Jule's, containing eighty-three acres, adjoining the lands of Garland Hanes, W. S. Dupree, W. A. Robinson, and others.
The dwelling has recently been repaired, and is sufficiently large for the accommodation of a small family.
There is also on the premises a large Barn, Stable, &c.--In the yard there is an excellent and never-failing spring of pure water.
The soil has been greatly improved in the last few years, and is particularly adapted to the growth of vegetables.
There is, also, on the place two good ice-houses, from one of which more than six thousand dollars worth of ice has been sold this summer.
Any person wishing a desirable and pleasant home near the city, and within the second line of fortifications, is especially invited to examine the same before the day of sale.
For particulars and terms apply to

div3.head: Sorghum Pans, Sorghum Pans.
div3.p:
Sorghum Pans of all sizes made to order at No. 166 Broad street, between Sixth and Seventh streets.
Call at once, as there is only a small lot of iron on hand.

By Davenport & Co., stock Auctioneers.
